Ammonia is a carbon-free hydrogen carrier, and development of non-noble metal catalyst to decompose ammonia into hydrogen is desirable for practical applications. However, the metal catalyst is challenged by the sintering of metal particles under high-temperature reaction conditions. In this study, a series of Li-, Al-, and Co-containing hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlc) were synthesized by co-precipitation and used as precursors to prepare well-dispersed and thermally stable Co nanoparticle catalysts for ammonia decomposition. The obtained precursors and catalysts were characterized by means of X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and so on. All of the precursors formed hydrotalcite-like phase, which consisted of Li–Al–(Co) HTlc and/or Co–Al HTlc dependent on the Co content. Upon calcination at 500 °C, HTlc decomposed into an Al-substituted Co3O4 spinel oxide, as confirmed by two distinctly separated reduction steps in H2-TPR. Following reduction at 700 °C, well-dispersed Co metal nanoparticles with an average particle size of ∼9.2–12.4 nm were obtained. It was suggested that the incorporation of Al3+ into Co3O4 led to a strong interaction between cobalt and aluminum, which suppressed the crystal growth of Co3O4 and the sintering of Co metal during the thermal treatments, resulting in good Co dispersion. The optimal LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst showed superior activity than that prepared by impregnation method, giving almost complete conversion of ammonia at 575 °C under a space velocity of 5,000 mL gcat –1 h–1. More importantly, this catalyst maintained stable activity at 625 °C for 100 h, exhibiting high stability and sintering resistance. The good catalytic performance was attributed to the high Co metal dispersion and strong metal–support interaction benefiting from the uniform distribution of cobalt in the HTlc precursor. These results demonstrate the applicability of HTlc to the preparation of metal catalysts with improved dispersion and thermal stability. Nowadays there are many kinds of hydrogen storage materials under research and development, including methanol, cyclohexane, metal hydrides, borohydrides, ammonia, metal ammine salts, amide/imide, and so on [1–4]. Among them, ammonia appears to be one of the most promising candidates due to its great advantages. (i) Ammonia has high hydrogen storage capacity, with a gravimetric density of 17.8 wt% H2 and a volumetric density of 212 kg H2 m–3 in liquid. (ii) Ammonia can be produced by the Haber-Bosch process, which is a mature technology allowing the economical large-scale synthesis of ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen. (iii) Ammonia is easily liquified by compression to 8 atm at atmospheric temperature, and there are established infrastructures for liquid ammonia storage and transportation. (iv) Ammonia can be catalytically decomposed into hydrogen and nitrogen without production of CO x , and the unconverted ammonia can be reduced to below 200 ppb by using a suitable adsorbent, so the H2 stream can be directly fed to a fuel cell without further purification steps. Therefore, on-site generation of high-purity hydrogen from ammonia provides a good solution to address the hydrogen storage and transportation issues. To this end, it is necessary to develop an efficient and cost-effective catalyst for ammonia decomposition. So far, many studies have been devoted to Ru, Fe, Co, Ni, and Mo [5–12] catalysts for ammonia decomposition. The noble-metal Ru catalysts (e.g. Ru/CNTs [13], Ru/MgO [14], Ru/CeO2 [15]) show state-of-the-art activity at low temperatures. However, its expense and scarcity limit the industrial applications. Therefore, there are substantial interests to develop non-noble metal catalysts for practical applications. Among non-noble metals, cobalt has advantages over nickel and iron. The nitrogen binding energy of cobalt is the closest to the optimal value, especially under high ammonia concentration [16]. So, it is expected to be the most active non-noble metal for ammonia decomposition. Several studies have confirmed the superior performance of Co catalysts [17,18]. For example, Hu et al. [17] prepared a Co/La-MgO catalyst, which exhibited higher activity and lower activation energy than Ni/La-MgO and Fe/La-MgO, and Zhang et al. [18] reported a Co/CNTs catalyst with better activity and lower activation energy compared to Ni/CNTs and Fe/CNTs. Various Co catalysts supported on carbon materials [18–22], Al2O3 [23–25], MgO–La2O3 [17,26–28], CeO2 [29–31], and SiO2 [32–35] have been developed, and their catalytic performances are strongly related to the Co dispersion and metal–support interaction depending on the metal content, nature of support, and preparation method. Despite the research progress, most of the non-noble metal catalysts including Co are still less active at low temperatures, and higher temperatures (e.g. >600 °C) are required to achieve high ammonia conversion. Under the high-temperature reaction conditions, one challenge for the metal catalysts is the deactivation due to the sintering of metal particles. Therefore, more effort is needed to prepare non-noble metal catalysts with improved thermal stability. Using hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlc) as precursor is a good way to prepare transition metal catalysts. HTlc is layered double hydroxides (LDH) with a general formula of [M2+ 1– x M3+ x (OH)2] x +(An– x /n)·mH2O [36], where M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent cations, respectively, including M2+ = Mg2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, or Zn2+, and M3+ = Al3+, Cr3+, Mn3+, Fe3+, or Ga3+; An– is an anion, such as F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, NO3 –, CO3 2–, SO4 2–, MoO4 2–, etc. The structure of M2+–M3+ HTlc is consisted of positively charged brucite-like layers with anions and water molecules intercalated between the layers for charge balance. Owing to the atomic level dispersion of metal cations in the brucite-like layers, thermal decomposition of HTlc usually produces homogeneous mixed metal oxides, which by reduction yield well dispersed and thermally stable metal nanoparticles. Many studies have reported the preparation of transition metal catalysts from Fe-, Co-, Ni-containing Mg–Al HTlc and their high catalytic performance for hydrogen production by ammonia decomposition and hydrocarbon reforming [37–41]. Besides those M2+–M3+ HTlc, there is a unique M +−M3+ HTlc that contains monovalent and trivalent cations, e.g., Li2Al4(OH)12CO3·mH2O [36]. The structure of Li–Al HTlc is constituted by gibbsite-like layers [LiAl2(OH)6]+, in which Li+ and Al3+ cations occupy one-third and two-thirds of the octahedral sites, respectively. Li–Al HTlc has been utilized as adsorbent [42], ion-exchanger [43], anti-corrosion protector [44], PVC stabilizer [45], catalyst [46], and precursor for LiAlO2 [47]. However, there are rare studies on the preparation of metal catalysts based on Li–Al HTlc and their catalytic applications. In this study, a series of HTlc containing different contents of Li, Al, and Co were synthesized by co-precipitation method and used as precursors to prepare Co catalysts for ammonia decomposition. The obtained precursors and catalysts were characterized by means of various techniques including inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). It was shown that calcination and reduction of Li, Al, Co-HTlc led to well dispersed Co metal nanoparticles, which exhibited good activity, stability, and sintering-resistance in the ammonia decomposition reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The LiAlCo HTlc precursors were synthesized at room temperature by co-precipitation method. The amount of chemicals used for HTlc synthesis is given in Table S1. By assuming a chemical formula of Li2Al4– x Co x HTlc, the molar ratio of (Al+Co)/Li was fixed at 2, and the Co content was varied to x = 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2. Under magnetic stirring, an aqueous solution containing the desired amounts of LiNO3, Al(NO3)3∙9H2O, and Co(NO3)2∙6H2O was dropped into a Na2CO3 solution. The solution pH was kept at 10±0.5 with a pH controller by adding a NaOH solution (2 mol L–1) though a peristaltic pump. After precipitation, the suspension was filtered, washed with de-ionized water, and dried at 100 °C overnight. The HTlc precursors were calcined at 500 °C for 5 h under air atmosphere to get mixed metal oxides (MMOs). The calcined samples were grounded to powders, and pressed into a disk, and then crushed and sieved to 30∼60 meshes. Finally, the calcined samples were reduced with H2 (30 mL min–1) at 700 °C for 0.5 h in a fixed bed reactor. For convenience, the obtained precursors, calcined samples, and reduced catalysts were denoted as LiAlCo(x)-HT, LiAlCo(x)-MMOs, and LiAlCo(x), respectively, where x referred to the Co content. The actual metal composition of the as-synthesized precursors was measured by ICP-OES and listed in Table 1 . For the purpose of comparison, a Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp catalyst was prepared by impregnation of LiAl-MMOs with Co(NO3)2 aqueous solution, followed by calcination and reduction treatments as described above. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The contents of Li, Al, and Co in the as-synthesized precursors were analyzed by ICP-OES on a Perkin-Elmer OPTIMA 8000 spectrometer. The crystalline structure of the precursors as well as those after calcination, reduction, and reaction was measured by XRD on a PANalytical X'PertPro diffractometer using monochromatized Co Kα radiation (λ = 1.789 Å). The working voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The texture property of the calcined samples was measured by N2 physical adsorption at –196 °C on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 apparatus. Prior to analysis, the sample was degassed in vacuum at 250 °C for 2 h The reducibility of the calcined samples was investigated by H2-TPR on Micrometrics AutoChem 2920. About 100 mg of sample was heated from ambient temperature to 950 °C (10 °C·min−1) in 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) mixed gas, and the H2 consumption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector. H2 chemisorption was also conducted on the same apparatus. The calcined sample (100 mg) was pre-reduced with H2 (30 mL min‒1) at 700 °C for 1 h, followed by purging with Ar (30 mL min‒1) for 0.5 h and then cooling down to 50 °C. H2 chemisorption was performed by pulsing a 10 vol.% H2/Ar gas until saturation adsorption, during which the H2 signal was detected by TCD. XPS was performed on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi spectrometer using Al Kα (1486.8 eV) as a monochromatic excitation source. The binding energy of C1 s (284.8 eV) was used for charge correction of the spectra. To obtain the spectra of the reduced catalysts, the sample was firstly ex-situ reduced with H2 at 700 °C for 0.5 h, and in-situ reduction in the XPS treatment chamber (H2, 500 °C, 0.5 h) was followed in order to diminish the influence of oxidation of Co metal by contact with air during the sample transfer. The morphology of the synthesized precursors was examined with FE-SEM on S4800 microscope (Hitachi) operating at 5.0 kV and 7 mA. HAADF-STEM-EDX measurement was performed on a JEM-2100 (JEOL) electron microscope with an operating voltage of 200 kV. The particle-size distribution of Co metal on the reduced catalysts was obtained by measuring about one hundred of particles. The average particle size was calculated by the equation: d = ∑nidi 3/∑nidi 2, where di was the particle's diameter, and ni was the number of particles with a diameter of di . 2.3 Catalytic performance test The ammonia decomposition reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed continuous flow quartz reactor under atmospheric pressure. Pure ammonia was used as feed gas and the flow rate was set to 25 mL min−1 with a mass flow meter. The space velocity was adjusted to 30,000, 10,000, and 5000 mL gcat –1 h–1 by loading 50, 150, and 300 mg sample, respectively. Prior to the reaction, the calcined sample was pre-reduced with H2 (30 mL min–1) by heating from room temperature to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C·min−1 and holding at 700 °C for 0.5 h In the activity test, the reaction temperature was raised from 350 °C to 750 °C at 25 °C intervals; at each temperature the reaction was maintained for 30 min. In the stability test, the reaction was run at 625 °C for 100 h under 30,000 mL gcat –1 h–1, during which the activity was evaluated every hour. The concentration of NH3 in the exit gas was analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph (GC9790II) equipped with a Poropak-Q column and a thermal conductivity detector using H2 as carrier gas. The ammonia conversion was calculated based on the flow rates of ammonia in the inlet gas and in the outlet gas. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the HTlc precursors Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the as-synthesized HTlc precursors. For Li2Al4 HT, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 13.6°, 23.5°, 27.5°, 42.2°, 47.5°, 56.4°, 74.9°, and 76.7° could be indexed to the (002), (101), (004), (112), (202), (008), (303), and (10,10) reflections of hexagonal Li2Al4(OH)12CO3·nH2O [48], confirming the formation of HTlc phase. Especially, the (101) reflection (d = 4.4 Å) is characteristic for Li–Al HTlc, which has been correlated with the ordered arrangement of Li+ and Al3+ cations in the LiAl2(OH)6 + gibbsite-like layers [48,49]. The appearance of this diffraction feature distinguishes Li–Al HTlc from other M2+–M3+ HTlc. In addition to those of Li–Al HTlc, there was a small diffraction peak at 2θ = 21.8°, which might be referred to Al(OH)3 (JCPDS 8–0096). The presence of Al(OH)3 might be due to the incomplete intercalation of Li+ in less concentrated Li+ solution and/or the de-intercalation of Li–Al HTlc during water washing [50,51]. For Co-containing precursors, no diffraction peaks due to cobalt hydroxide (e.g. β-Co(OH)2) were observed, indicating that Co2+ was completely incorporated within the HTlc structure. This was confirmed by the absence of IR band due to β-Co(OH)2 (ca. 3633 cm–1) [52] (Fig. S1). At low Co content (x = 0.5), there was no obvious change in the XRD pattern except that the peak shape was broadened. It was suggested that Co2+ was incorporated into the gibbsite-like layers to form Li–Al–Co HTlc. As the Co content rose to x = 1∼1.5, the (101) diffraction peak characteristic for Li–Al HTlc was diminished, and two diffraction peaks at 2θ = 72.0° and 73.4° assignable to the (110) and (0015) reflections of Co–Al HTlc appeared (Fig. S2), implying the formation of a mixture of Li–Al–Co HTlc and Co–Al HTlc. With further increasing the Co content up to x = 2, Co–Al HTlc was dominant. This indicated that formation of Co–Al HTlc was favorable at high Co contents. For comparison, a series of Li-free CoAl samples were synthesized by the same procedure, which showed the formation of Co–Al HTlc phase with the increase of Co content (Fig. S3), in line with the above result. As listed in Table 1, the interlayer distance (c 0) of HTlc was estimated to be ∼0.75 nm from the position of the (002) or (003) reflection, and the average crystallite size in c direction was calculated to decrease from 12.7 to 5.4 nm by the Scherrer equation. The SEM images of the as-synthesized HTlc precursors are illustrated in Fig. S4 and Fig. 2 a. All of the precursors exhibited a nanoplatelet morphology typical of HTlc. The nanoplatelets were arranged in random directions, which displayed irregular shape but with relatively uniform size and thickness. Fig. 2b shows a TEM image of LiAlCo(1.5)-HT and a layered structure was identified. The lattice fringe spacing was measured to be 0.78 nm (Fig. 2c), which coincided with the interlayer distance calculated from XRD. The HAADF-STEM-EDX images in Fig. 2d revealed that the constituent elements Co, Al, and O were evenly distributed and homogeneously mixed with each other, in accordance with the atomic distribution of metal cations in the hydroxide layers of HTlc. By the way, Li is not easy to detect by EDX due to its low-energy radiation characteristic. The actual metal compositions of the as-synthesized precursors measured by ICP-OES are listed in Table 1. The Li content was slightly lower than the nominal value for LiAl-HT, which might be attributed to the incomplete intercalation of Li+ into Al(OH)3 and/or the partial release of Li+ from Li–Al HTlc during water washing [50,51]. Furthermore, the Li content decreased markedly with the increase of Co content, in agreement with the transformation of HTlc from Li–Al HTlc to Co–Al HTlc. 3.2 Characterization of the calcined samples The XRD patterns of the calcined samples are shown in Fig. 3 . Upon calcination at 500 °C, LiAl HTlc was decomposed into poorly crystalline γ-Al2O3, as indicated by the broad diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.6°, 53.5°, and 79.0°. No diffraction peaks associated with Li2O or LiAlO2 were detected, indicating that Li species was highly dispersed or inserted into the γ-Al2O3 lattice. As the Co content rose, the diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 were attenuated, and an XRD pattern characteristic of spinel became dominant. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 22.2°, 36.6°, 43.3°, 45.3°, 52.8°, 65.9°, 70.5°, and 77.9° matched well with the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), and (440) reflections of Co3O4 spinel with a face-centered cubic Fd3 m space group, indicative of the formation of cobalt spinel oxide. This cobalt spinel oxide might be assigned to Al-substituted Co3O4 (denoted as Al-Co3O4), as discussed later. For Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs, a similar spinel XRD pattern was presented. However, the diffraction peaks were strong and sharp, ascribable to the formation of well-crystalline Co3O4. The calculated lattice parameter and average crystallite size of the cobalt spinel oxides are given in Table 1. The lattice parameter was similar for all spinel oxides, but the crystallite size was much smaller for Li–Al–Co MMOs compared to Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs, suggesting a high thermal stability of Al-Co3O4. Similar results have been reported for the Al-MgO and Al-NiO mixed oxides obtained by calcination of HTlc precursors, and the incorporation of Al into the oxide lattice to form magnesium or nickel aluminate-type phases is suggested to be responsible for the enhanced sintering resistance [53,54]. A similar explanation might be applicable to Al-Co3O4. Table 1 also lists the BET specific surface areas of the calcined samples. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions are presented in Fig. S5. All samples displayed an IV-type isotherm with a hysteresis loop at the range of p/p 0 = 0.4∼1.0. For Li–Al–Co MMOs, there was an increased number of mesopores with the most probable pore diameter of ∼9 nm. The presence of a suitable amount of cobalt in Li–Al–Co MMOs led to an increase of surface area. The BET surface area increased first and then decreased with the increase of cobalt content, which might be ascribed to the formation of mesoporous Al-Co3O4 and the presence of cobalt aluminate-like species (vide infra), respectively. On the other hand, a decrease in the surface area was observed on Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs, ascribable to the pore blockage by large crystalline Co3O4. The chemical state of Co species in the calcined samples was investigated by XPS. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , all of the Co 2p spectra resembled that of Co3O4 [55–58], confirming the cobalt spinel oxide to be Co3O4 or its analogs. The spin-orbit doublets Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 were present at ∼780 eV and ∼795 eV with an energy difference of ∼15 eV, and the satellite peaks were weak due to the presence of diamagnetic Co3+. According to the literature [22,55,59], the Co 2p main peaks were deconvoluted into two components. The peak at 779.5 eV corresponded to Co3+, and the peak at 780.5 eV was assigned to Co2+. The binding energies (BEs) are listed in Table 2 . It was noticed that the Co 2p BEs increased with the increase of Co content, indicating enhanced interaction between cobalt and aluminum oxides. For Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs, the Co 2p spectrum was much less intense and the Co 2p BEs were lower as compared to LiAlCo(1.5)-MMOs. This might be interpreted as due to the formation of large crystallite Co3O4 that weakly interacted with aluminum oxide. The reducibility of cobalt species and its interaction with aluminum oxide in the calcined samples were further investigated by H2-TPR. The obtained profiles are shown in Fig. 5 A. No reduction peak was observed for LiAl-MMOs. The Li–Al–Co MMOs samples displayed a broad peak below 475 °C and a strong peak with maximum at ∼600 °C, along with a small peak above 700 °C. These reduction peaks might be associated with different cobalt species and/or the stepwise reduction of cobalt spinel oxide. As reported previously, the reduction of Co3O4 occurred in one or two closely overlapping steps below 500 °C (Co3O4 → CoO → Co0) [60–62], and CoAl2O4 spinel started to reduce above 700 °C [62,63]. To analyze the reduction process, the Li–Al–Co MMOs samples were reduced at 475 °C, a temperature at which the first reduction process was completed. The structure change after this reduction treatment was measured by XRD. As shown in Fig. 5B, the diffraction peaks of spinel disappeared, and an XRD pattern analogous to CoO standard diffractogram emerged. Note that the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.3°, 51.1°, and 75.2° were shifted to higher angles compared to CoO standard diffractogram. In addition, there was an absence of diffraction peaks due to γ-Al2O3 at high Co contents. Accordingly, the CoO-like phase was ascribable to Al-substituted CoO (Al-CoO). The incorporation of Al3+ into CoO induced lattice contraction due to its smaller ionic radius (0.0535 nm) than Co2+ (0.0745 nm) [64]. The presence of Al-CoO indicated that the original cobalt spinel oxide was different from Co3O4 and CoAl2O4. One possible explanation is that Al3+ was incorporated in the Co3O4 lattice to form Al-Co3O4. In fact, the formation of Al-substituted metal oxides (e.g. Al-MgO, Al-NiO) upon calcination of HTlc has been well reported, which can be relevant to the homogeneous distribution of metal cations in HTlc. Based on this analysis, the first peak in H2-TPR was assigned to the reduction of Al-Co3O4 to Al-CoO. Following this, the second peak was attributed to the reduction of Al-CoO to Co metal, which was corroborated by the disappearance of Al-CoO after reduction at 700 °C (Fig. 6 ). Obviously, Al-Co3O4, which involved two distinctly separated reduction steps, was more difficult to reduce than Co3O4 [60–62], manifesting a strong interaction between cobalt and aluminum oxides. Regarding the reduction peak above 700 °C, it might be assigned to cobalt aluminate-like species [62]. This peak was prominent on LiAlCo(2)-MMOs (max. at ∼755 °C), indicating a decrease of cobalt reducibility. For comparison, the same reduction treatment was done on Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs, too. In this case, the disappearance of cobalt spinel oxide was accompanied by the presence of Co metal, assignable to the reduction of Co3O4 to Co metal. Besides, the diffraction peaks due to γ-Al2O3 remained intense, suggesting that the majority of Al3+ maintained the pristine state. Thus, Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp-MMOs was thought to comprise mainly Co3O4, which aggregated on the support surface and was in weak interaction with aluminum oxide. In H2-TPR (Fig. 5A-f), the reduction peak present at 500∼700 °C (max. at ∼605 °C) might be related to surface Co2+ ions interacting with Al2O3 support [62,65]. 3.3 Characterization of the reduced catalysts The XRD patterns of the Co reduced catalysts are presented in Fig. 6. Upon reduction at 700 °C, the diffraction peaks of spinel disappeared, and those at 2θ = 51.9°, 60.6°, and 91.2° corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) reflections of Co metal appeared, indicating that the cobalt spinel oxide was totally reduced to Co metal. For the Li–Al–Co catalysts, the diffraction peaks of Co metal were rather weak, manifesting the formation of well-dispersed Co metal particles. It was hard to calculate the crystallite size of Co metal by the Scherrer equation due to the low peak intensity. As for Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp, the diffraction peaks of Co metal were strong and sharp. The average crystallite size of Co metal was calculated to be 21.3 and 15.9 nm using the Co (111) and (200) reflections, respectively. To further inspect the dispersion state of Co metal on the reduced catalysts, HAADF-STEM was performed. Fig. 7 shows the HAADF-STEM images and particle-size distributions of Co metal on the reduced catalysts. For the Li–Al–Co catalysts (Fig. 7a–d), the Co metal particles were well dispersed and evenly distributed without obvious aggregation. The particle size was ranged between 5 and 20 nm, and the average particle size was calculated to be 9.2, 11.0, 12.0, and 12.4 nm for LiAlCo(0.5), LiAlCo(1), LiAlCo(1.5), and LiAlCo(2), respectively. In contrast, for Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp (Fig. 5e), severe aggregation of Co metal particles was observed. The particle size was varied in a broad range from 10 to 30 nm with an average size as large as 19.2 nm. Apparently, LiAlCo(1.5) possessed higher Co dispersion than Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp, demonstrating the merit of using HTlc as catalyst precursor. This property might be related to the formation of Al-Co3O4 upon decomposition of HTlc, which led to a strong interaction between cobalt and aluminum that suppressed the crystal growth of Co3O4 and the sintering of Co metal during the calcination and reduction treatments. Fig. 8 presents the Co 2p XPS spectra of the reduced catalysts. The Co 2p3/2 BEs are listed in Table 2. In all cases, a distinct peak at 777.9 eV corresponding to metallic Co0 [66,67] was identified, confirming the formation of Co metal. Meanwhile, there was a peak at ∼781.0 eV together with a satellite peak at ∼786 eV, both of which might be related to hardly reducible Co2+ species that strongly interacted with aluminum oxide. For the HTlc-reduced catalysts, the Co2+ species was suggested to be surface cobalt aluminate-like species. Such a species, which was not detected by XRD (Fig. 6), might form at the surface of Al-Co3O4 as is the case of the formation of magnesium or nickel aluminate phases on the HTlc-derived Al-MgO and Al-NiO mixed oxides [53,54]. The intensity of the Co2+ peaks increased with the increase of Co content, suggesting the formation of more cobalt aluminate species. This also implied as a greater extent of cobalt–aluminum interaction. Likewise, the intensity of the Co0 peak increased with increasing the Co content up to x = 1.5, indicative of the presence of larger amounts of surface Co0. Nonetheless, with further increasing the Co content, a decrease in the Co0 peak was observed. As listed in Table 2, the Co0/Co2+ ratio decreased to a low level at Co content x = 2, which might be ascribed to the formation of a larger amount of unreducible cobalt aluminate species, as indicated by the increase of the reduction peak above 700 °C in H2-TPR. For Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp, the Co2+ species might be assigned to unreduced surface Co2+ ions that strongly interacted with the Al2O3 support. The Co0/Co2+ ratio was relatively high, attributable to a high reduction degree of cobalt and a low extent of cobalt–aluminum interaction. According to the XRD and H2-TPR results, the calcined Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp comprised mainly large crystallite Co3O4 that weakly interacted with aluminum oxide. The Co3O4 species was readily reduced to metallic Co at low temperatures, resulting in high Co reduction degree. However, the resulting Co metal had large particle size so that the number of surface Co0 would be small. To measure the number of surface Co0, H2 chemisorption was performed. As listed in Table 1, LiAlCo(1.5) showed the largest amount of H2 uptake (534 μmol-H2 gcat –1), much higher than that of Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp (386 μmol-H2 gcat –1). In short, the LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst possessed a suitable metal–support interaction, which led to suitable Co particle size and an appropriate amount of Co0 active sites. 3.4 Catalytic performance for ammonia decomposition Fig. 9 a shows the temperature-dependence of ammonia conversion over the Co catalysts under a space velocity of 30,000 mL gcat –1 h–1. For reference, the reaction was also tested for the blank quartz reactor. In the absence of catalyst, the ammonia conversion was very low, which approached to zero at temperatures below 600 °C and gave only 14% as the temperature was raised to 750 °C. In the presence of LiAl sample, the ammonia conversion increased to a certain extent but not more than 43%, indicating that the LiAl mixed oxide was not active enough for ammonia decomposition. On the other hand, a remarkable increase in the ammonia conversion was observed in the presence of Co catalyst. Typically, the ammonia conversion increased with the reaction temperature, since ammonia decomposition is an endothermic reaction. The catalyst activity increased with the increase of Co content from x = 0.5 to 1.5 and then decreased as the Co content further rose to x = 2.0. Among the HTlc-derived catalysts, LiAlCo(1.5) showed the highest activity, which gave 53% and 98% ammonia conversion at 550 °C and 650 °C, respectively. This might be attributed to its larger amount of surface Co0 active sites as indicated by H2 chemisorption. In comparison, the Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp catalyst prepared by impregnation method was less active than LiAlCo(1.5), which gave only 27% and 84% ammonia conversions at 550 °C and 650 °C, respectively. This activity difference could be attributed to the higher Co dispersion for LiAlCo(1.5) as revealed by XRD, HAADF-STEM, and H2 chemisorption. Based on the ammonia conversion data (below 20%) at 425∼525 °C, the Arrhenius plots were obtained, as shown in Fig. 9b. The apparent activation energy (Ea ) was calculated to be ∼96 kJ mol–1, almost identical for the HT-derived catalysts, suggesting a structural and chemical similarity of these catalysts. In addition, the E a values were slightly lower than that of Co(1.5)/LiAl-imp, which might be ascribed to the different Co dispersion and metal–support interaction. Many studies have reported the promoting effect of alkali metals to Ru catalysts [68,69], where alkali metals act as an electron promoter by donating electrons to Ru. To examine the influence of Li, a Li-free Co1.5Al2.5 catalyst was prepared from Co1.5Al2.5 HTlc by the same procedure and compared with LiAlCo(1.5). Both catalysts showed almost the same ammonia conversion (Fig. S6), suggesting that the presence of Li had small influence on the catalytic activity. This is different from the case of Ru catalyst. At present, it is hard to explain the different effects of Li on Co and Ru catalysts. Further, the LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst was evaluated under different space velocities. As shown in Fig. 9c, the ammonia conversion increased with the decrease of space velocity. Nearly full conversion of ammonia was achieved at 600 °C and 575 °C when the space velocity was decreased to 10,000 and 5000 mL gcat –1 h–1, respectively. Table S2 compares the catalytic activities of some Co catalysts reported for ammonia decomposition. LiAlCo(1.5) showed a relatively high activity, which was comparable to Co/CeO2 [29], Co/MgO-La2O3 [27], and Co/perovskite [70], and performed much better than the Co catalysts supported on SiO2 [34,35], 1D titanate nanotubes [71], and Co-containing CNTs [72] under similar reaction conditions. Herein, it must be mentioned that the catalytic activity of metal catalysts for ammonia decomposition is strongly dependent on the geometric and electronic properties of active metal. Although the LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst processed high Co content and dispersion, the catalytic activity was probably limited by the electronic state of Co metal, given the low electron-donating ability of aluminum oxide and Li species. It is expected to improve the catalyst activity by modifying the electronic state of Co with a strongly basic oxide (e.g. MgO), which will be conducted in the near future. Fig. 9d shows the change of ammonia conversion with time-on-stream at 625 °C over LiAlCo(1.5), with an aim to investigate the high-temperature thermal stability of the catalyst. There have been several studies reporting the deactivation of Co catalyst at temperatures ≤600 °C, e.g., Co/γ-Al2O3 [24,73,74], Co/La2O3 [75], and Co0.7Sm0.3O x [76]. By comparison, LiAlCo(1.5) exhibited an excellent long-term stability. The ammonia conversion maintained constant (∼95%) during the whole test period. In order to confirm the structural stability of the catalyst, XRD and HAADF-STEM were performed after the long-term test. As shown in Fig. S7, the XRD pattern of the used catalyst was analogous to that of the freshly reduced catalyst, and no obvious change in the crystalline structure was found. The HAADF-STEM image and particle-size distribution of Co metal are presented in Fig. 7f. As can be seen, Co metal nanoparticles remained well dispersed, and the particle-size distribution and average particle size (12.3 nm) had no obvious change, indicating that the Co metal nanoparticles possessed good resistance against sintering under the high-temperature reaction conditions. Such a result is interesting given the high cobalt content of LiAlCo(1.5), and this could be attributed to the strong metal–support interaction between Co nanoparticles and aluminum oxides derived from Al-Co3O4 spinel. 4 Conclusions The synthesized Li-, Al-, and Co-containing hydrotalcite-like compounds consisted of Li–Al–(Co) HTlc and/or Co–Al HTlc dependent on the Co content. Decomposition of HTlc gave rise to an Al-substituted Co3O4 spinel oxide, which led to a strong interaction between cobalt and aluminum that suppressed the crystal growth of Co3O4 and the sintering of Co metal during the thermal treatments, resulting in the formation of well dispersed Co metal nanoparticles. The optimal LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst was superior to that prepared by impregnation method, which showed nearly full ammonia conversion at 575 °C under 5000 mL gcat –1 h–1. Moreover, this catalyst exhibited excellent long-term stability and sintering-resistance during 100 h test at 625 °C. The good catalytic performance might be related to the high Co dispersion and strong metal–support interaction. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia is a carbon-free hydrogen carrier, and development of non-noble metal catalyst to decompose ammonia into hydrogen is desirable for practical applications. However, the metal catalyst is challenged by the sintering of metal particles under high-temperature reaction conditions. In this study, a series of Li-, Al-, and Co-containing hydrotalcite-like compounds (HTlc) were synthesized by co-precipitation and used as precursors to prepare well-dispersed and thermally stable Co nanoparticle catalysts for ammonia decomposition. The obtained precursors and catalysts were characterized by means of X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and so on. All of the precursors formed hydrotalcite-like phase, which consisted of Li–Al–(Co) HTlc and/or Co–Al HTlc dependent on the Co content. Upon calcination at 500 °C, HTlc decomposed into an Al-substituted Co3O4 spinel oxide, as confirmed by two distinctly separated reduction steps in H2-TPR. Following reduction at 700 °C, well-dispersed Co metal nanoparticles with an average particle size of ∼9.2–12.4 nm were obtained. It was suggested that the incorporation of Al3+ into Co3O4 led to a strong interaction between cobalt and aluminum, which suppressed the crystal growth of Co3O4 and the sintering of Co metal during the thermal treatments, resulting in good Co dispersion. The optimal LiAlCo(1.5) catalyst showed superior activity than that prepared by impregnation method, giving almost complete conversion of ammonia at 575 °C under a space velocity of 5,000 mL gcat –1 h–1. More importantly, this catalyst maintained stable activity at 625 °C for 100 h, exhibiting high stability and sintering resistance. The good catalytic performance was attributed to the high Co metal dispersion and strong metal–support interaction benefiting from the uniform distribution of cobalt in the HTlc precursor. These results demonstrate the applicability of HTlc to the preparation of metal catalysts with improved dispersion and thermal stability.
